channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Zelensky outlines what he’d consider Ukrainian victory
item.dc:creator: Liz Sly
item.description: The Russian holiday might come with increased missile strikes, local leaders warned. Meantime, the ‘next stage’ of the Mariupol is evacuation underway and Hungary is resisting the E.U.'s oil ban.

item.title: Pentagon sending Ukraine laser-guided rockets, new surveillance drones
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe

item.title: At least eight dead as explosion rocks luxury hotel in Havana
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: Firefighters and rescue workers searched the rubble of the Hotel Saratoga for additional victims. Authorities said preliminary investigation indicated the cause was a gas leak.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Zelensky outlines what he’d consider Ukrainian victory
item.dc:creator: Liz Sly
item.description: The Russian holiday might come with increased missile strikes, local leaders warned. Meantime, the ‘next stage’ of the Mariupol is evacuation underway and Hungary is resisting the E.U.'s oil ban.

item.title: Pentagon sending Ukraine laser-guided rockets, new surveillance drones
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe

item.title: At least eight dead as explosion rocks luxury hotel in Havana
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: Firefighters and rescue workers searched the rubble of the Hotel Saratoga for additional victims. Authorities said preliminary investigation indicated the cause was a gas leak.

item.title: A history of Russian oppression fueled Lithuania’s energy independence
item.dc:creator: Jeanne Whalen
item.description: A long history of oppression drove Lithuania's push to end its dependence on Russian energy supplies.

item.title: A tragedy at sea shakes Lebanon’s poorest city
item.dc:creator: Sarah Dadouch
item.description: At least seven people died last month after a boat carrying migrants to Europe from Lebanon capsized. At least 20 people are still missing.

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Tories lose some key local elections; Sinn Fein awaits count
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam
item.description: The British midterm elections are seen as a referendum on Johnson’s leadership.

item.title: Is U.S. a liberal outlier on abortion as leaked draft opinion says?
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Many countries permit abortions after legal cutoffs under a wide range of exceptions.

item.title: In the Philippines, grass-roots campaign takes on the Marcos juggernaut
item.dc:creator: Regine Cabato
item.description: While Ferdinand Marcos Jr. holds a substantial lead in polls, Leni Robredo’s volunteers are trying to turn the tide with door-to-door canvassing and online activism.

item.title: Where pregnancy is a deadly gamble
item.dc:creator: Danielle Paquette
item.description: Sierra Leone is one of the riskiest places to have a baby. One teen fears repeating her mother’s story of dying in childbirth.

item.title: China’s unvaccinated elderly prevent an end to covid lockdowns
item.dc:creator: Eva Dou
item.description: China's vaccination strategy initially prioritized the young, and now the elderly are the most unvaccinated segment of society, jeopardizing any effort to relax restrictions.

item.title: How millions of Russians are tearing holes in the Digital Iron Curtain
item.dc:creator: Anthony Faiola
item.description: A tremendous surge in VPN downloads represents a challenge to Putin and his version of the Ukraine war.

item.title: Three people killed in ax attack near Tel Aviv, Israeli medics say
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix
item.description: The attacks were the latest in a recent string of deadly assaults on civilians, according to public safety officials and Israeli media.

item.title: Another rescue effort underway in Mariupol; U.S. intel helped Ukraine sink warship
item.dc:creator: David L. Stern
item.description: Russia ramps up attacks on Ukraine's infrastructure as Mariupol officials lose contact with remaining troops at the Azovstal steel plant.

item.title: Video shows Russian ‘filtration camp,’ Mariupol mayor’s office says
item.dc:creator: Joyce Sohyun Lee
item.description: Displaced Ukrainians from Mariupol were allegedly threatened by Russian soldiers with torture and executions at the filtration camp.

item.title: Mariupol siege endgame means very different things for Kyiv and Moscow
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: For Ukrainians, it will likely be remembered as a heroic last stand. But for the Kremlin, it’s belated justification of claims to be “de-Nazifying” Ukraine.

item.title: Russia tightens grip on Mariupol as Ukraine seeks more Western aid
item.dc:creator: David L. Stern
item.description: A Pentagon spokesman said most Russian forces who had been fighting in Mariupol have left and gone north, a sign that Russia feels it has control of the city.

item.title: A race against time in Ukraine as Russia advances, West sends weapons
item.dc:creator: Liz Sly
item.description: Russia has adapted its tactics and Ukrainian forces are feeling the toll of two months of fighting, compounding the urgency of new U.S. and European weapons supplies arriving soon.

item.title: U.S. provided intelligence that helped Ukraine sink Russian warship
item.dc:creator: Shane Harris
item.description: The United States provided Ukraine with intelligence that helped Kyiv identify, attack and sink the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet, the Moskva, in one of the most dramatic battlefield successes of the 71-day-old war, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: American killed in Ukraine was a volunteer, fellow fighters say
item.dc:creator: Razzan Nakhlawi
item.description: The 22-year-old veteran believed to be the first American killed while fighting in the Ukrainian military was serving as a volunteer, not a private contractor, two fellow fighters said Thursday, contradicting earlier reports suggesting the latter.

item.title: Russian oligarch’s $300 million yacht seized by Fiji on behalf of U.S.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: The Justice Department announced that Fiji executed a seizure warrant on the Amadea, a 348-foot-long luxury vessel owned by Russian oligarch Suleyman Kerimov that authorities say was “subject to forfeiture based on probable cause of violations of U.S. law.”

item.title: Powerful blast at Havana hotel kills 8 people, injures 40
item.dc:creator: Andrea RodrÍguez | AP
item.description: A powerful explosion apparently caused by a natural gas leak has blown away outer walls from a five-star hotel in the heart of Cuba’s capital, killing eight people and injuring at least 40

item.title: Brazil's Amazon deforestation hits record for month of April
item.dc:creator: Fabiano Maisonnave | AP
item.description: Deforestation detected in the Brazilian Amazon reached a record high for the month of April

item.title: Explosion at Madrid building leaves 2 dead, 18 injured
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: City officials in Madrid say an explosion ripped through a four-story residential building in the center of the Spanish capital, injuring at least 18 people

item.title: Saudi coalition transfers Yemeni prisoners as part of truce
item.dc:creator: Ahmed Al-Haj | AP
item.description: The Red Cross says that 117 Yemeni prisoners held by the Saudi-led coalition have arrived in the southern port city of Aden as a truce deal between the warring parties entered its second month

item.title: 'We're so sorry': Mariupol plant evacuees feel relief, grief
item.dc:creator: Cara Anna | AP
item.description: More than 100 civilians have finally emerged from the bombarded Azovstal steel plant, the last Ukrainian holdout in the ruined city of Mariupol

item.title: Israeli minister touts plans to approve 4,000 settler homes
item.dc:creator: Areej Hazboun | AP
item.description: Israel’s interior minister says plans will be advanced for the construction of 4,000 settler homes in the occupied West Bank

item.title: Israel searches for attackers who killed 3 in mass stabbing
item.dc:creator: Joseph Krauss | AP
item.description: Israeli security forces are carrying out a massive manhunt for two Palestinians suspected in a mass stabbing near Tel Aviv that left three Israelis dead

item.title: Danish tourist killed in roadside bombing in northern Iraq
item.dc:creator: Salar Salim | AP
item.description: Iraqi Kurdish officials say a Danish national was killed by a roadside bomb while cycling in northern Iraq, blaming Turkish Kurdish insurgents for planting the device

item.title: Two Islamic extremist attacks kill 11 Burkina Faso soldiers
item.dc:creator: Sam Mednick | AP
item.description: Burkina Faso’s army says 11 security forces were killed and nine injured in two jihadi attacks in northern Burkina Faso

item.title: Andrew, Harry and Meghan won't appear on Jubilee balcony
item.dc:creator: Danica Kirka | AP
item.description: Buckingham Palace has finally answered one of the biggest remaining questions about Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations
